Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project Grant: Application of Lessons from Model Institutions for Excellence (ALEMIE): A Comprehensive Support for Minority Students at Elizabeth City State Unive

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The overall goal of the targeted infusion project at Elizabeth City State University is to address the high rate of attrition of students from introductory biology courses. This effort will be achieved by utilizing a holistic approach to student retention that relies on several strategies including evaluation of best practices that enhance African American student success, implementation of best practices, implementation of a pre-college initiative with targeted mentoring, a summer bridge program with a critical thinking component and online experiences as a prelude for e-learning. All of these strategies are reinforced through a strategically developed partnership with Rutgers University that meaningfully includes learning and education program evaluation expertise, particularly as it relates to African American students. It is envisaged that the outcomes of this project will be analyzed in terms of the ease of transferability to a research intensive institution. In this regard, the targeted infusion project at Elizabeth City State University will not only impact the institution, but also impact non-HBCU campuses and, therefore, a broader cadre of underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recognition of a high student attrition rate in introductory level science courses at Elizabeth City State University (a minority-serving and a constituent institution of the University of North Carolina), and with the goal of enhancing the success of minority students during their first two years of college experience, we evaluated for three years the impact of select best practices of the Model Institutions for Excellence on course-level student success and overall student retention. Four of the seven select tested methods we used included 1) precollege bridge program, 2) continuous student support including a mandatory tutorial, 3) undergraduate research experience and 4) graduate school and science career preparation.

Our overall assessment by including a total of 25 undergraduate student participants is that these interventions work. Our project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas of a total of 29 students (25 participants and 4 mentors) whom 26 were African Americans & two Caucasian women. The implemented ALEMIE (Application of Lessons from Model Institutions of Excellence) program’s overall retention was 76% over four years, i.e. 20% higher than overall departmental retention for the same period.  

Those who already graduated did so in less than 9 semesters and the remaining are in their junior or senior year and are in good academic standing with 30% maintaining a GPA >3.0. We anticipate all of them to graduate in less than 10 semesters. The 20% who interrupted their studies (5 students out of a total of 25 participants) did so for non-academic reasons. For those where reason for leaving was disclosed, we know two transferred to bigger North Carolina colleges. All maintained a GPA of >2.5 at the time of their withdrawal. Only one out of 25 was suspended for academic reason, and that was due to health problems.

The program has helped many of its participants get undergraduate research experience. Exposure to research as undergraduates provides critical skills in research and confidence that empowers participants and helps them develop confidence towards research careers in sciences and aspirations towards a terminal degree. A case in point is one of the undergraduate tutors of the program is now a PhD student at a research-intensive university and the graduate mentor is now serving as the Biology teacher in the local high school. Three other graduates of the program are now waiting to hear decisions on their graduate applications. 

The relatively high retention rate and successful completion of participant students opens career opportunities and will eventually contribute to the diversity of US work force in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. Because this pilot project has enabled us test and confirm the practical positive implications of these interventions on the retention of minority students, especially of those from rural areas such as the economically distressed northeaster North Carolina, we currently are exploring ways how we can expand and scale up these interventions to provide academic support a larger group of students from disadvantaged groups.
